intro: Cheiranthus albus, commonly known as the white wallflower, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes mustard and cabbages, and is characterized by its small, four-petaled flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with hairy stems and alternate, lance-shaped leaves. Its flowers, which are usually white or pale yellow, bloom in early spring and are followed by elongated pods containing small, round seeds. Cheiranthus albus is often found in disturbed soils and can thrive in rocky or sandy environments.
